title: American_Top_40_1971_May_29th
description:
"From the Florida Everglades to the California Redwoods, you hear the nation's top hits every week at this time on AT40."


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This recording is one I found on the internet.

In this countdown:

A 19-year-old Hawaiian girl (who would eventually become part of the Saturday Night Fever Soundtrack) and the Australian-American woman (known for singing "I Am Woman") both have the same song in the countdown. 

Jerry Reed has the highest debuting song of the week, "When You're Hot, You're Hot" (at number 32).

On her way to number 1, Carole King moves her song "It's Too Late" up 17 notches from number 38 to number 21.

Casey says he got a letter which asked, "Which song had the biggest drop of any song ever on the Billboard chart?" Casey tells about a 1969 song that fell from number 12 clean off the chart. 

That same letter-writer also asks if Casey is the guy who plays Dexter Carter on ABC's Saturday morning cartoon, "Hot Wheels." Yes, Casey was the voice of Dexter Carter, and I've included a snippet of that cartoon for you to see. Play it with VLC Media Player, a free download.

Murray Head is at number 14 with his song "Superstar." He would chart again in 1984 with "One Night In Bangkok."

Finally, Matthew's Southern Comfort is at number 23 with a song written by Joni Mitchell, "Woodstock." It would later be remade by Crosby, Stills, Nash, & Young, and reach number 11 on Billboard's hot 100. I've included that version as a RocketMan Extra.

39: Double Lovin' - The Osmonds
